description:
The Torque teno midi virus 12 (TTMV12) is a small, circular, single-stranded DNA virus that belongs to the Anelloviridae family. This virus is classified as a member of the Middivirus genus within the Anelloviridae family.

TTMV12 is known to infect humans and has been detected in various human tissues and body fluids, including blood, liver, and respiratory samples. The virus is believed to have a relatively high prevalence in the human population, with many individuals harboring TTMV12 as a persistent, asymptomatic infection.

The genome of TTMV12 is approximately 3.2 kilobases in length and encodes several viral proteins, including the putative viral capsid protein. The exact biological functions and replication mechanisms of TTMV12 are not yet fully understood, but it is thought to utilize a DNA-based replication strategy similar to other members of the Anelloviridae family.

While the clinical significance of TTMV12 infection remains a topic of ongoing research, the virus has been associated with various human diseases and conditions, including liver disease, immunodeficiency, and cancer. However, the exact role of TTMV12 in the development of these diseases is still under investigation, and further research is needed to elucidate the potential pathogenic mechanisms and clinical implications of TTMV12 infection.
